messages.subject: Re: Thoughts about this tsuba ?
messages.msgSnippet: Just for clarity Curran it did get swaped out and was never submitted.  It ll hold till next shinsa My read on the theme was cricket ior katydid on a fern
messages.messageBody:
Just for clarity Curran it did get swaped out and was never
submitted. It'll hold till next shinsa
My read on the theme was cricket ior katydid on a fern frond
Thanks
Kirk

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Thoughts about this tsuba ?
messages.msgSnippet: Jim, I took the tsuba to shinsa, but may have not submitted it. I believe the owner made a substitution (he had only so many slots and given me more items than
messages.messageBody:
Jim,

I took the tsuba to shinsa, but may have not submitted
it. I believe the owner made a substitution (he had
only so many slots and given me more items than he had
slots). Same owner as the Myochin.

The design is exactly the same as Rich's, but it did
not feel Akasaka. The mimi on Akasaka usually feels
more full, rounded. Then the actual plate on the tsuba
was ~perfectly~ flat and the sukashi so crisp in
execution that it felt almost machined precise in
execution.
I mentally ruled out Akasaka, and was curious to
see the shinsa results on it. The fact that I don't
would point towards either (a) early senility or (b)
that this was the one substituted out.

Jim, (sidenote) at the time I was surprised at the
Myochin call on the other tsuba. I would have thought
that it ended up in some group I was less familiar
with. Interesting tsuba.

Any preview on the Yagyu exhibit for those
international listeroos that won't get to see it?

Curran



--- Jim Gilbert <jggilbert@...> wrote:

> Curran,
> Number 482 was a Myochin tsuba with a circular cross
> section rim and a design of two large diamond shapes
> at 12:00 and 6:00. That's the only thing similar in
> your group. I know the owner, so I'm guessing it's
> the one you're thinking of.
>
> I've seen the spiral motif used on a guard signed
> Tadatoki, and as Rich said the insect is often seen
> in Akasaka sukashi. I don't think Akasaka is a bad
> call.
>
> Rich, what's putting you off Akasaka?
>
> Back to the Yagyu,
> Jim
>
>
>
> Rich,
>
> At the Chicago 2004 NTHK Shinsa, I papered a near
> identical (very pristine condition) tsuba for a
> friend. I do not remember what the attribution
> was-
> but I know it was not Akasaka.
>
> I do not know if Jim G. has easy access to those

> between

>

> thought you might also appreciate the Hagihara
> notes
> on the similar tsuba.
>
> Curran

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Thoughts about this tsuba ?
messages.msgSnippet: ooohh, yagu, that s teasing :-). Tell us more...... Thanks Jim, I guess the Mimi was what threw me, though my Tadatoki mokume tsuba s mimi is as square as my
messages.messageBody:
ooohh, yagu, that's teasing :-). Tell us more......

Thanks Jim, I guess the Mimi was what threw me, though my Tadatoki
mokume tsuba's mimi is as square as my last assistant, and that's
square. I think the sharpness of the sukashi is Akasaka-ish, as is the
design as a whole. I thought Akao because of it's overall boldness and
the fact that they were copying Akasaka along with Tosa Myochin and visa
versa at the later stages of the Edo period.

Though, from the photo's, I would think this a bit older than late Edo ?.

Cheers

Rich

Jim Gilbert wrote:

> Curran,
> Number 482 was a Myochin tsuba with a circular cross section rim and a
> design of two large diamond shapes at 12:00 and 6:00. That's the only
> thing similar in your group. I know the owner, so I'm guessing it's
> the one you're thinking of.
>
> I've seen the spiral motif used on a guard signed Tadatoki, and as
> Rich said the insect is often seen in Akasaka sukashi. I don't think
> Akasaka is a bad call.
>
> Rich, what's putting you off Akasaka?
>
> Back to the Yagyu,
> Jim
>

--
*Richard Turner - Nihonto Message Board*
/for the discussion of all things Nihonto./
www.nihontomessageboard.com <http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/nmb/>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Thoughts about this tsuba ?
messages.msgSnippet: Curran, Number 482 was a Myochin tsuba with a circular cross section rim and a design of two large diamond shapes at 12:00 and 6:00.  That s the only thing
messages.messageBody:
Curran,
Number 482 was a Myochin tsuba with a circular cross section rim and a design of two large diamond shapes at 12:00 and 6:00. That's the only thing similar in your group. I know the owner, so I'm guessing it's the one you're thinking of.

I've seen the spiral motif used on a guard signed Tadatoki, and as Rich said the insect is often seen in Akasaka sukashi. I don't think Akasaka is a bad call.

Rich, what's putting you off Akasaka?

Back to the Yagyu,
Jim



Rich,

At the Chicago 2004 NTHK Shinsa, I papered a near
identical (very pristine condition) tsuba for a
friend. I do not remember what the attribution was-
but I know it was not Akasaka.

I do not know if Jim G. has easy access to those
records, but I believe the tsuba was somewhere between
the submissions # 460 to 485.

Jim can probably identify it out of hand, but I
thought you might also appreciate the Hagihara notes
on the similar tsuba.

Curran



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] new release / Yamanaka NL
messages.msgSnippet: Hi: I did not know that the Yamanaka Newsletter had been reorganized. It was its serial and disjointed format that made it awkward to use, but its
messages.messageBody:
Hi:
I did not know that the Yamanaka Newsletter had been reorganized. It was its serial and disjointed format that made it awkward to use, but its comprehensiveness more than made up for that. Also, the late Robert M. Lewert put out a quite complete and reasonably accurate index of the NL in its original form, so if one had that it was never a probelm to access. Thanks for the additional information Jim.
AF



>>> jggilbert@... 08/05/05 7:02 PM >>>
To clarify for those who haven't seen it, this is more than just a reprint of Albert Yamanaka's original work. Paul Allman took apart a set of the original newsletters and rearranged them according to a logical table of contents. The first two volumes are as easily accessed as the Nihonto Koza or similar encyclopedia.

Volume I covers Koto, arranged by the classical road system.

Volume II is Shinto and Shin-Shinto, followed by History of the Japanese Sword, Identification of Nihonto through Shape, and Definition of Nihonto and its Nomenclature.

Volume III includes Historical figures, Famous Swords in Japanese History, Kokuho, Missing Kokuho and Juyo Bijutsu and Kyoho Meibutsu Cho

Volume IV continues Kyoho Meibutsu Cho, several articles by others, the Tokugawa Jikki and an extensive compilation of Random Thoughts.

Some of the most interesting material is in later two volumes, but an index would greatly enhance their usability.

The Allman version came out over ten years ago, but was "off the market" until recently. I see that latest offering does not include binding of the four volumes, so be sure to get them into some sort of binding before the pages get mixed up.

Jim


Everyone can latch on to one, because the NCJSC reprinted it.

http://www.ncjsc.org/NCJSC_Publications_4_04.pdf


Hi:
The Yamanaka Newsletter is second to none as a useful source of comprehensive and detailed information on the Japanese sword - coming as a newsletter it has certain natural limitations of easy use, ie, it isn't easy to use, but it is virtually without peer.
If you can latch onto one, do!
AF

>>> jdz@... 08/04/05 11:21 AM >>>
I would strongly recommend additionally:

Albert "Kozan" Yamanaka, reformatted by Paul R. Allman, The Nihonto Newsletters, 4 volumes, San Francisco: Northern California Japanese Sword Club, (1994), 2004.




[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
